div.p: Arrangement whereby a work is undertaken by a publisher, who upon publication of the work in question renders to the author a full account covering the printing, advertising, and possibly also distribution costs; upon receiving this account, the author advances the necessary sums, or calls on his patron to do so. The publisher issues periodic sales reports, and the author is paid a contractually agreed percentage of the sales of non-review and non-complimentary copies.
This arrangement contrasts with publication in a regular publishing house, in which the publisher bears the total costs, and the author receives a periodic royalty.

Schenker's Neue Musikalische Theorien und Phantasien , vols. I (Harmonielehre) and II/1 (Kontrapunkt 1) were published in the commission publishing house of J. G. Cotta'sche Nachfolger in 1906 and 1910 respectively, and the two accounts were met by Baron Alphons von Rothschild, Schenker's principal patron at the time.
